main event: A bright red-orange object was observed moving up and down in the sky, remaining in a general direction.
interesting points: The object's azimuth and elevation were almost precisely the location of Venus, which was prominent in the sky at the time.
The variation in size and apparent motion were likely the result of atmospheric effects on the view of Venus.
The object was described as a rectangular line, 1 to 2 inches long and 16 inches long, bright red-orange in color.
The object was observed while the witness was driving down the highway, at an elevation of 32 degrees and an azimuth of 323 degrees.
The object was observed moving up and down, with fast maneuvering, and its disappearance was unknown.
result: The sighting was likely caused by atmospheric effects on the view of the planet Venus.
witnesses: A Catholic priest, age 47, from St. Louis, Missouri
photographs: No photographs were included in the report.
